body:
I'm going to state a controversial one and say Mussolini. 

Unfortunately his collaboration with Nazi Germany was arguably motivated as a quasi-desperate attempt to keep the invasion of Italy at bay. He allowed the Nazi initiatives on Italian territory to take place and it is no surprise the Nazis overstepped their boundaries and destroyed/stole/killed without second thought. It is what led to his reputation in history and ultimate downfall.

Putting that aside, many considered him a benevolent dictator. He was fascinated with Ancient Rome, the beauty of its architecture, the structure of its society, and the well-being it offered to its citizens as dominant empire of the known world. He emulated their example and wanted what was best for his people in hoping to create a new 'Italian Empire' of the Mediterranean. He introduced radical economic restructuring that providing housing to the poor, jobs for the greater majority of the population, incredible new infrastructure, and positive growth opportunities of which the Italian people haven't seen since in over 70 years.

Even today many still regard him as the last great emperor of Rome, an honorary title which he surely would have appreciated.

body:
It is very well possible, although his military strategies and aspirations in North Africa have often been criticized and simply lacked the force he thought he had at his disposal.

It's easy to criticize in retrospect, but as opposed to focusing on territorial acquisition had he continued to build the wealth of the Italian territory as well as he did, these states may have willingly joined in time. I imagine a sort of alternate future where as opposed to a "European Union" a "Mediterranean Union" may have formed.

As an aside, interestingly enough when Ancient Rome had various territories under its control, Romans born citizens enjoyed special privileges (the right to vote and be elected) compared to secondary citizens of the client states. If the subject interests you, you can read more about that here:
[Roman Citizenship | Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_citizenship)

post.title: What historical figure gets an undeserved bad reputation?

body: King Henry VIII. Most people regard him as an ogre. While he was certainly not perfect, he was actually popular with the English people. Also, people don't seem to realize that his obsessive hunt for a male heir was not for his own benefit, but the country's. Before his father became king, England had been embroiled in civil war for generations because of squabbles over succession. Having a male heir would prevent that from occurring after his own death.

parent.body:
I'm going to state a controversial one and say Mussolini. 

Unfortunately his collaboration with Nazi Germany was arguably motivated as a quasi-desperate attempt to keep the invasion of Italy at bay. He allowed the Nazi initiatives on Italian territory to take place and it is no surprise the Nazis overstepped their boundaries and destroyed/stole/killed without second thought. It is what led to his reputation in history and ultimate downfall.

Putting that aside, many considered him a benevolent dictator. He was fascinated with Ancient Rome, the beauty of its architecture, the structure of its society, and the well-being it offered to its citizens as dominant empire of the known world. He emulated their example and wanted what was best for his people in hoping to create a new 'Italian Empire' of the Mediterranean. He introduced radical economic restructuring that providing housing to the poor, jobs for the greater majority of the population, incredible new infrastructure, and positive growth opportunities of which the Italian people haven't seen since in over 70 years.

Even today many still regard him as the last great emperor of Rome, an honorary title which he surely would have appreciated.

parent.body:
I'm going to state a controversial one and say Mussolini. 

Unfortunately his collaboration with Nazi Germany was arguably motivated as a quasi-desperate attempt to keep the invasion of Italy at bay. He allowed the Nazi initiatives on Italian territory to take place and it is no surprise the Nazis overstepped their boundaries and destroyed/stole/killed without second thought. It is what led to his reputation in history and ultimate downfall.

Putting that aside, many considered him a benevolent dictator. He was fascinated with Ancient Rome, the beauty of its architecture, the structure of its society, and the well-being it offered to its citizens as dominant empire of the known world. He emulated their example and wanted what was best for his people in hoping to create a new 'Italian Empire' of the Mediterranean. He introduced radical economic restructuring that providing housing to the poor, jobs for the greater majority of the population, incredible new infrastructure, and positive growth opportunities of which the Italian people haven't seen since in over 70 years.

Even today many still regard him as the last great emperor of Rome, an honorary title which he surely would have appreciated.

body:
Not arguing against the point that he was a benevolent dictator, but all the points you made could be said about a lot of dictators.

Many dictators want what's "best for the people", the problem lies in how they define what exactly that is, and what's an acceptable way to achieve it. Most of what you said would also be applicable to, say, Mao Zedong. You should point out what specifically sets Mussolini apart.

body:
> I agree, that's a good point. Here is a comprehensive list translated from Italian, I apologize if it is a bit long, and with Google Translate it may be a bit wonky:

At the advent of Fascism large areas of the peninsula were drowned in unhealthy swamps; who was forced to live in those areas rarely exceeded the 40th year of age. These unhealthy areas stretched from Veneto to Emilia Romagna, from the Tuscan Maremma to the Agro Pontino, from the plains of Garigliano, Volturno, Sele to the Tavoliere delle Puglie and Basilicata, from the Piana di Sibari to the lands of Sila and Neto. And so for the plain of Catania and for the Campidano in Sardinia. Thus, when in the thirties the whole world was subjugated by the profound economic crisis, in Italy a gigantic work of land transformation and restoration of the territory began.

Much of the credit goes to the wise agricultural policy inspired and piloted by Arrigo Serpieri who promoted numerous laws of a fundamental nature including L. 3256/1923 on water reclamation and soil protection and L. 753/1924 on public agricultural transformations interest; he organized and directed the first application of the "Complete reclamation" (Mussolini Law). Epurao in the post-war period by the democratic Bonomi government because it was fascist.

* 1925 Beginning of the Battle of the Wheat. In 1925 imports of cereals amounted to 25,000,000,000 quintals and accounted for 4 billion lire, about half of the deficit of the Italian trade balance. In 1931, with a production of 81,000,000 quintals, Italy for the first time almost entirely covers its need for cereals.
* 1926 Attack on the Sicilian latifundio: the landowners went from 54,760 in 1911 to 222,612 in 1926. National parks of Gran Paradiso, Stelvio, Abruzzo and Circeo
* 1929 Reclamation works begin: large areas of the peninsula were drowned in unhealthy swamps; who was forced to live in those areas rarely exceeded the 40th year of age. These unhealthy areas extended from North to South. It begins with the reclamation of the Agro Pontino, entrusted to the O.N.C. 3,040 farmhouses, 499 km of roads, 205 km of canals, 15,000 km of small schools were built in the Agro Pontino; plowed 41,600 hectares of land. 14 new villages built.
* 1930 Mussolinia of Sardinia founded, in Oristano (today Arborea)
* 1932 Agro Pontino: Littoria today Latina inaugurated
* 1933 Agro Pontino: Littoria inaugurated
* 1934 Agro Pontino: Sabaudia inaugurated (judged to be one of the finest examples of European urban planning)
* 1935 Agro Pontino: Pontinia inaugurated
* 1936 Cervinia in the Aosta Valley inaugurated
* 1936 Felicia founded, today the Slovenian Cvic
* 1936 Founded Arsia, in Istria (today Resa)
* 1937 Agro Pontino: Guidonia inaugurated, founded in 1935
* 1937 Agro Pontino: Aprilia inaugurated
* 1937 Carbonia is founded (reclamation of Sulcis - Sardinia)
* 1938 Metaurilia founded, near Fano
* 1938 Guidonia opens
* 1939 Agro Pontino: Pomezia inaugurated, founded in 1938
* 1939 Mussolinia of Sicily inaugurated (today Case M… olinia)
* 1939 Acilia founded near Ostia
* 1939 Reclamation of the unhealthy areas of the Volturno (Molise)
Volania inaugurated in the Ferrara area
Tirrenia inaugurated, near Livorno
Segezia opens in Basilicata
Marconia in Lucania inaugurated
Remediation of unhealthy areas in the Veneto
Reclamation of the unhealthy areas of the Po Valley
Remediation of unhealthy areas of Emilia-Romagna
Remediation of unhealthy areas of the Tuscan Maremma
Remediation of unhealthy areas of the Garigliano plain (Abruzzo)
Remediation of Maccarese, in the Roman countryside: an agricultural-livestock-nursery model company, built on 5,000 hectares of reclaimed land with hundreds of houses, experimental fields, social cellars, managed by over 1,500 workers.
Reclamation of the Holy Island in Rome, with the foundation of Acilia and Ardea
Reclamation of the unhealthy areas of the Sele (Campania)
Remediation of the unhealthy areas of the Tavoliere delle Puglie
Reclamation of the unhealthy areas of Basilicata
Remediation of the unhealthy areas of the Piana di Sibari (Calabria)
Remediation of the unhealthy areas of Sila (Calabria)
Remediation of unhealthy areas of Neto (Calabria)
Remediation of unhealthy areas of the Catania plain
Reclamation of the unhealthy areas of Campidano (Sardinia)
Founded Fertilia, near Alghero

The results of reclamations and rural laws: 5,886,796 hectares reclaimed, between 1923 and 1938, a comparison is necessary between the pre-fascist period, when in 52 years they were reclaimed in the entire Peninsula just 1,390,361 hectares. Add 32,400 kilometers of roads; 5,400 aqueducts; 15 new cities (in addition to those mentioned, we remember Fertilia, Segezia, Alberese, Mussolinia, today Alborea, Tirrenia, Tor Viscosa, Arsia and Pozzo Littorio) and hundreds of villages; over a million hectares of land reforested; one million rural buildings; the increase in production which went from 100 to 2,438; agricultural work per hectare which increased from 100 to 3,618; the workers employed in the reclamation works and in the new farms exceeded 500 thousand units. Nor should we forget the defeat of malaria which caused hundreds of deaths every year.

Another significant figure on the technical quality achieved in the agricultural sector by our country, is the comparison between the 16.1 quintals of wheat per hectare reached in the reclaimed lands and the US production, considered the best, stops at 8.9 quintals / hectare.
The attribution of farm workers in the reclamation areas is the flagship of rural policy
fascist. As you can see, goals that changed the face of Italy.

In 1922 there were more than 2 million laborers: in the early 1940s their number was reduced to just 700 thousand units, the others had become owners, sharecroppers or partners of small or large companies.

**Economy**

* 1923 Ansaldo, Banco di Roma and Ilva (1923 - 1924) are saved from bankruptcy.
* 1924 Balance sheet.
* 1927 The Labor Charter - Work is a social duty protected by the state. Its purpose is the well-being of producers and the development of national power. Collective labor agreements express the solid- between the various factors of production, through the reconciliation of the opposing interests of employers and workers and their subordination to the higher interests of production. The initiative private is the most effective and most useful tool in the interest of the nation. State intervention in production it takes place only when the private initiative is missing or insufficient, or when the political interests of the state are at stake. It was a document that prohibited the use of the strike and lockout, and directly delegated any conciliatory action to the authority of the fascist state.
* 1929 The world crisis that broke out in 1929 in the United States had made its effects felt in Italy in the 1930: collapse of stock prices by 40%; agricultural production - 11%; manufacturing production - 15%; unemployment to one million people. The main banks that had lent large sums to companies by accepting the shares of debtor companies as collateral, when the companies went into crisis and became insolvent, remained with a mountain of pieces of paper (the shares) worthless. The state first bought the shares of the banks, then took on the major industrial investments by saving banks and businesses from bankruptcy. Thus protected millions of small savers from bank insolvencies IMI and IRI are established.
* 1929 The world of capitalism is in chaos: the Duce responds with 37 billion public works and in 10 years 11,000 new classrooms are built in 277 municipalities, 6,000 public housing housing 215,000 people, 3131 popular economic buildings, 1,700 housing, 94 public buildings, reconstruction of earthquake victims, 6,400 sheltered houses, aqueducts, hospitals, 10 million inhabitants in 2493 municipalities had insured water, 4,500 km of hydraulic and embankment accommodation, Navicelli canal; In 1922 there were 54 artificial mountain basins, in 1932 they had reached 184, 6 million and 663 kw increased and 17,000 km of power lines; in 1932 there were 2,048 km of electric railways for a saving of 600,000 tons of coal; 6,000 km of state, provincial and municipal roads built, 436 km of highways.
* 1931 IMI (Italian securities institute): for the purchase of shares of troubled banks. Capital is born-Stateism. The communists destroyed capital, Fascism used it for the common good. The new institution has as its main purpose the exercise of medium-term credit, it must collect savings, through the issue of ten-year bonds, to direct it towards the financing of rescue and relaunch initiatives for industries in difficulty to because of the great crisis.
* 1933 IRI (Institute for Industrial Reconstruction): for the purchase and development of industrial enterprises. Economic body entrusted with the task of providing twenty-year loans to industries with money obtained through the placing on the market of government-guaranteed bonds. The disposable section acquires important shareholdings of industries in the various sectors, telephone, maritime, construction, financial, mechanical, steel. In 1934, IRI acquired control of most large credit institutions and comes into possession of the shares of the industries they hold. Trade agreements with all states, including the USSR.
* 1936 Banking reform: between 1936 and 1938 the Bank of Italy passed completely into public hands and its Governor assumed the role of Inspector on the exercise of credit and the defense of savings

  • 1937 Agro Pontino: Aprilia inaugurated
  • 1937 Carbonia is founded (reclamation of Sulcis - Sardinia)
  • 1938 Metaurilia founded, near Fano
  • 1938 Guidonia opens
  • 1939 Agro Pontino: Pomezia inaugurated, founded in 1938
  • 1939 Mussolinia of Sicily inaugurated (today Case M… olinia)
  • 1939 Acilia founded near Ostia
  • 1939 Reclamation of the unhealthy areas of the Volturno (Molise) Volania inaugurated in the Ferrara area Tirrenia inaugurated, near Livorno Segezia opens in Basilicata Marconia in Lucania inaugurated Remediation of unhealthy areas in the Veneto Reclamation of the unhealthy areas of the Po Valley Remediation of unhealthy areas of Emilia-Romagna Remediation of unhealthy areas of the Tuscan Maremma Remediation of unhealthy areas of the Garigliano plain (Abruzzo) Remediation of Maccarese, in the Roman countryside: an agricultural-livestock-nursery model company, built on 5,000 hectares of reclaimed land with hundreds of houses, experimental fields, social cellars, managed by over 1,500 workers. Reclamation of the Holy Island in Rome, with the foundation of Acilia and Ardea Reclamation of the unhealthy areas of the Sele (Campania) Remediation of the unhealthy areas of the Tavoliere delle Puglie Reclamation of the unhealthy areas of Basilicata Remediation of the unhealthy areas of the Piana di Sibari (Calabria) Remediation of the unhealthy areas of Sila (Calabria) Remediation of unhealthy areas of Neto (Calabria) Remediation of unhealthy areas of the Catania plain Reclamation of the unhealthy areas of Campidano (Sardinia) Founded Fertilia, near Alghero

The results of reclamations and rural laws: 5,886,796 hectares reclaimed, between 1923 and 1938, a comparison is necessary between the pre-fascist period, when in 52 years they were reclaimed in the entire Peninsula just 1,390,361 hectares. Add 32,400 kilometers of roads; 5,400 aqueducts; 15 new cities (in addition to those mentioned, we remember Fertilia, Segezia, Alberese, Mussolinia, today Alborea, Tirrenia, Tor Viscosa, Arsia and Pozzo Littorio) and hundreds of villages; over a million hectares of land reforested; one million rural buildings; the increase in production which went from 100 to 2,438; agricultural work per hectare which increased from 100 to 3,618; the workers employed in the reclamation works and in the new farms exceeded 500 thousand units. Nor should we forget the defeat of malaria which caused hundreds of deaths every year.

Another significant figure on the technical quality achieved in the agricultural sector by our country, is the comparison between the 16.1 quintals of wheat per hectare reached in the reclaimed lands and the US production, considered the best, stops at 8.9 quintals / hectare. The attribution of farm workers in the reclamation areas is the flagship of rural policy fascist. As you can see, goals that changed the face of Italy.

In 1922 there were more than 2 million laborers: in the early 1940s their number was reduced to just 700 thousand units, the others had become owners, sharecroppers or partners of small or large companies.

Economy

  • 1923 Ansaldo, Banco di Roma and Ilva (1923 - 1924) are saved from bankruptcy.
  • 1924 Balance sheet.
  • 1927 The Labor Charter - Work is a social duty protected by the state. Its purpose is the well-being of producers and the development of national power. Collective labor agreements express the solid- between the various factors of production, through the reconciliation of the opposing interests of employers and workers and their subordination to the higher interests of production. The initiative private is the most effective and most useful tool in the interest of the nation. State intervention in production it takes place only when the private initiative is missing or insufficient, or when the political interests of the state are at stake. It was a document that prohibited the use of the strike and lockout, and directly delegated any conciliatory action to the authority of the fascist state.
  • 1929 The world crisis that broke out in 1929 in the United States had made its effects felt in Italy in the 1930: collapse of stock prices by 40%; agricultural production - 11%; manufacturing production - 15%; unemployment to one million people. The main banks that had lent large sums to companies by accepting the shares of debtor companies as collateral, when the companies went into crisis and became insolvent, remained with a mountain of pieces of paper (the shares) worthless. The state first bought the shares of the banks, then took on the major industrial investments by saving banks and businesses from bankruptcy. Thus protected millions of small savers from bank insolvencies IMI and IRI are established.
  • 1929 The world of capitalism is in chaos: the Duce responds with 37 billion public works and in 10 years 11,000 new classrooms are built in 277 municipalities, 6,000 public housing housing 215,000 people, 3131 popular economic buildings, 1,700 housing, 94 public buildings, reconstruction of earthquake victims, 6,400 sheltered houses, aqueducts, hospitals, 10 million inhabitants in 2493 municipalities had insured water, 4,500 km of hydraulic and embankment accommodation, Navicelli canal; In 1922 there were 54 artificial mountain basins, in 1932 they had reached 184, 6 million and 663 kw increased and 17,000 km of power lines; in 1932 there were 2,048 km of electric railways for a saving of 600,000 tons of coal; 6,000 km of state, provincial and municipal roads built, 436 km of highways.
  • 1931 IMI (Italian securities institute): for the purchase of shares of troubled banks. Capital is born-Stateism. The communists destroyed capital, Fascism used it for the common good. The new institution has as its main purpose the exercise of medium-term credit, it must collect savings, through the issue of ten-year bonds, to direct it towards the financing of rescue and relaunch initiatives for industries in difficulty to because of the great crisis.
  • 1933 IRI (Institute for Industrial Reconstruction): for the purchase and development of industrial enterprises. Economic body entrusted with the task of providing twenty-year loans to industries with money obtained through the placing on the market of government-guaranteed bonds. The disposable section acquires important shareholdings of industries in the various sectors, telephone, maritime, construction, financial, mechanical, steel. In 1934, IRI acquired control of most large credit institutions and comes into possession of the shares of the industries they hold. Trade agreements with all states, including the USSR.
  • 1936 Banking reform: between 1936 and 1938 the Bank of Italy passed completely into public hands and its Governor assumed the role of Inspector on the exercise of credit and the defense of savings

parent.body:
Not arguing against the point that he was a benevolent dictator, but all the points you made could be said about a lot of dictators.

Many dictators want what's "best for the people", the problem lies in how they define what exactly that is, and what's an acceptable way to achieve it. Most of what you said would also be applicable to, say, Mao Zedong. You should point out what specifically sets Mussolini apart.

post.title: What historical figure gets an undeserved bad reputation?

author.bio: You've come here to dig up dirt, probably because you lost an argument and are now resorting to petty tactics. My opinions may offend, in a free society that's acceptable. Much love and peace.

body:
* 1936 Cinecittà Foundation - In 1935, after the destruction due to a fire, the studies of the house of Cinema production, was identified along the via Tuscolana, in the middle of the Roman countryside, an area of ​​approximately 500,000 square meters for the construction of the new city of cinema. Work began on January 26, 1936 with the laying of the first stone and after only fifteen months, on April 28, 1937, the inauguration of the new Quadraro factories took place. The plans for the first twelve stage theaters were elaborated by the architect Gino Peressuti; in addition to these, the creation of an industrial center was envisaged integrated cinematographic strial which included development, printing and assembly plants, the new headquarters of the Istituto Luce and that of the Centro Sperimentale di Cinematografia.
* 1937 Rural and Artisan Boxes - R.D. 26/08/1937 n. 1706
* 1944 Corporate socialization - Law of the R.S.I.

**Railways**

* 1931 Inauguration of the new Milan central railway station. Construction had started in 1913 but then suspended for the war. With a new design and with 341 meter long steel arches (covering an area of ​​66,500 square meters), construction began at a steady pace in 1925. The facade is 200 meters wide and the vault 72 is high (a record by then) . It is still considered one of the most beautiful stations in the world. Inauguration of the Santa Maria Novella station in Florence
* 1932 Rome - Viterbo railway inaugurated
* 1934 The direct Bologna - Florence route was inaugurated
* 1934 The Littorina is born: one of these railcars makes the 12,000 km trip Turin, Moscow, Leningrad, Black Sea, Moscow, Turin. It makes the crossing Baltic Sea - Black Sea in 35 hours (25 hours less of the fastest local trains, setting a record of time still unbeaten). The entire network was enlarged and almost electrified; the replaced rolling stock. Italy had the most equipped and efficient railway network in Europe.
* 1938 Beginning of the Rome metropolitan construction (60% completed in 1940)
* 1923 Forestry Code (establishment of the Forestry Guard)
* 1923 Law on hydraulic reclamation and soil protection
* 1923 Law on agricultural transformations of public interest
* 1923 Establishment of the State Archive
* 1927 The Labor Charter was published
* 1928 Mussolini Law: Complete remediation with works entrusted to the ONC - R.D. 24/12/1928 n. 3134
* 1929 Signature of the Lateran Pacts
* 1930 Criminal Code
* 1933 Code of Criminal Procedure
* 1933 Bank and Circular Check Law
* 1936 Tourism legislation
* 1936 Banking law. It reorganizes the banking system and prohibits ordinary credit banks from making long-term loans.
* 1940 Code of Civil Procedure
* 1940 Navigation Code
* 1942 Civil Code
Consolidated Law on Public Safety Laws
Traffic laws

**Social laws**

* 1923 School Reform (Gentile Reform)
* 1923 The activity of the Mussolini government was a constant succession of decrees and laws with clear social aims at the forefront not only in Italy but even in the world. Those laws, of which the Italian workers still enjoy the privileges, are those desired by Mussolini in his twenty years of government. Any comparison with what has been done by the governments of this post-war period would be striking.
* 1923 Disability and old-age insurance - R.D. 30/12/1923 n. 3184
* 1923 Hospital assistance to the poor - R.D. 30/12/2003 n. 2841
* 1923 Protection of the work of women and children - R.D. 26/04/1923 n. 653
* 1923 Establishment of full trade unionism with the union of employers' trade union representatives (Confindustria and Confagricoltura)
* 1925 National Opera Maternity and Childhood (O.N.M.I.) - R.D. 10/12/1925 n. 2277. They came to visit works foreign speakers to study its organization (in 1934 the Chinese delegation)
* 1925 Illegitimate and abandoned or exposed assistance - R.D. 08/05/1925 n. 798
* 1926 Unemployment insurance - R.D. 12/30/1926 n. 3158
* 1927 Labor Charter (see Economy)
* 1927 Compulsory assistance against TB - Constitution of Provincial Consortia - R.D. 27/10/1927 n. 2055
* 1928 Tax exemption for large families - R.D. 05/14/1928 n. 1312
* 1928 Compulsory insurance against occupational diseases - R.D. 13/05/1928 n. 928
* 1929 National Opera Orphans of War - R.D. 26/07/1929 n. 1397
* 1935 I.N.P.S. - National Social Security Institute - R.D. 04/10/1935 n. 1827
* 1937 40-hour working week - R.D. 29/05/1937 n. 1768
* 1933 I.N.A.I.L .: National Institute for Insurance against Accidents at Work - R.D. 23/03/1933 n. 264
* 1937 E.C.A .: Municipal Assistance Body - R.D. 03/06/1937 n. 817
* 1937 Family allowances - R.D. 17/06/1937 n. 1048
* 1943 I.N.A.M .: Institute for Worker Illness Assistance - R.D. 11/01/1943 n. 138
Autonomous Institute of Popular Houses
National Institute for State Employee Homes
National Opera Dopolavoro (in 1935 it had 771 cinemas, 1227 theaters, 2066 theater, 2130 orchestras, 3787 bands, 1032 professional and cultural associations, 6427 libraries, 994 choral schools, 11159 sports sections, 4427 competitive sports.). The communists called it the people's house.
Fight against illiteracy: from 1923 to 1936 we went from 3,981,000 to 5,187,000 pupils; Student's medium teeth from 326,604 to 674,546, university from 43,235 to 71,512.
After-school for the completion of the pupils
Physical education compulsory in schools
Fight against malaria
Marine and mountain colonies
School meals
Scholastic obligation up to 14 years
Professional schools
Labor Judiciary
School card
FAO foundation

**Mafia**

Another "great success" of the regime was the fight against the mafia. The protagonist of this enterprise was
Cesare Mori, the so-called "Iron Prefect".

When Mussolini came to power, finding himself among other things facing the problem of banditry and the Sicilian mafia, he was made the name of Mori. Mussolini said: "I want it to be just as hard on the mobsters as it has been on my Bolognese squads." "State authority must be absolutely, I repeat absolutely, re-established in Sicily. If the laws currently in force obstruct it, it will not be a problem. We will make new laws. " Even if the mafia was not completely liquidated, it fell so to speak "to sleep". The American godparents who returned to the island in 1943 after the landing of the Allied troops will wake it up.

**Marina**

* 1925 Civil and military marine enhancement: in 1932 it is among the most important in the world
* 1931 Launch of the Amerigo Vespucci school ship
Genoa's new maritime station
Launch of the transatlantic Rex: the most sophisticated and fastest ship in the world: Gibraltar New York in 4 days, 13 hours and 58 minutes.
* 1937 The battleship Vittorio Veneto was launched
* 1940 Completion of the Porto Marghera basin to bring ships to the armament plants and repair
Port of Naples
Port of Messina

**Architectural works and infrastructures**

* 1927 Idroscalo of Milan. In 1927 Fascism passed a law for the construction of a "Idroscalo" for the city of Milan. Real sea, even salty, sandy shore, marine pines, bathers, lifeguards. The "Idroscalo" is a large gully 3 km long and 300 meters wide with 300 head for aircraft maneuvers. The basin occupies an area of ​​610,000 square meters. It is fed by spring waters. The Idroscalo has always been- to reported as quagmire. The Duce has transformed it into a basin, a lake, a "slice" of sea with all marine characteristics. This spectacular miracle was inaugurated in 1930. The beach has 100 cabins, has its "promenade", with trees around it, hotels, amusement parks, sports fields, meadows. At the center of the basin there is an island that can be easily reached by boat and find all the fun there.
Palazzo della Previdenza Sociale in each provincial capital
* 1930 Verona: General warehouses with cutting-edge refrigeration systems in Europe
Rome: Viale della Conciliazione
Rome: Metro
Rome: Stadio dei Marmi (in front of the huge obelisk with the inscription "Mussolini Dux")
Rome: University city inaugurated in 1935
Rome: Palazzo della Farnesina, seat of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs
Rome: foundation of Cinecittà (works started in 1936, finished in 1937)
* 1931/4 Venice. In 657 days the bridge of the Littorio (today of Liberty) was built, which connects Venice to the mainland. And since towards the end the engineer Eugenio Miozzi realized he had spent less than he spent they had given him, he decided to use the surplus to build, in front of the railway station, a new bridge that would cross the Grand Canal, the Scalzi bridge (built in Istrian stone, without any armor). The work began 9 days after the inauguration of the Ponte del Littorio by the Duce and was ready in 542 days. And since towards the end of this second work he realized that he had spent less than expected, he decided to demolish the old iron bridge of the Academy (in pitiful conditions) to replace it with a temporary wooden one. Felling, debris removal, construction of the new building and inauguration: one month. And the beautiful wooden bridge is still there. Creation of the car terminal in Piazzale Roma (1931-1933). Construction of the garage of Sant'Andrea, one of the major works of rationalist architecture in Venice (1931-1934). Construction of the Municipal Casino on the Lido (1937-1938).
* 1932 Rome: Inauguration of the new headquarters of the Ministry of Corporations
* 1937 Rome: EUR construction begins (was to be inaugurated in 1943)
* 1937 Rome: Construction of the National Light Institute begins
* 1938 Rome: Inauguration of the Ara Pacis
Rome: Via dell’Impero between the Colosseum and Piazza Venezia
Creation of the Empire architectural style
* 1928 The Venice Biennale is born

parent.body:
> I agree, that's a good point. Here is a comprehensive list translated from Italian, I apologize if it is a bit long, and with Google Translate it may be a bit wonky:

At the advent of Fascism large areas of the peninsula were drowned in unhealthy swamps; who was forced to live in those areas rarely exceeded the 40th year of age. These unhealthy areas stretched from Veneto to Emilia Romagna, from the Tuscan Maremma to the Agro Pontino, from the plains of Garigliano, Volturno, Sele to the Tavoliere delle Puglie and Basilicata, from the Piana di Sibari to the lands of Sila and Neto. And so for the plain of Catania and for the Campidano in Sardinia. Thus, when in the thirties the whole world was subjugated by the profound economic crisis, in Italy a gigantic work of land transformation and restoration of the territory began.

Much of the credit goes to the wise agricultural policy inspired and piloted by Arrigo Serpieri who promoted numerous laws of a fundamental nature including L. 3256/1923 on water reclamation and soil protection and L. 753/1924 on public agricultural transformations interest; he organized and directed the first application of the "Complete reclamation" (Mussolini Law). Epurao in the post-war period by the democratic Bonomi government because it was fascist.

* 1925 Beginning of the Battle of the Wheat. In 1925 imports of cereals amounted to 25,000,000,000 quintals and accounted for 4 billion lire, about half of the deficit of the Italian trade balance. In 1931, with a production of 81,000,000 quintals, Italy for the first time almost entirely covers its need for cereals.
* 1926 Attack on the Sicilian latifundio: the landowners went from 54,760 in 1911 to 222,612 in 1926. National parks of Gran Paradiso, Stelvio, Abruzzo and Circeo

Thus, when in the thirties the whole world was subjugated by the profound economic crisis, in Italy a gigantic work of land transformation and restoration of the territory began.

post.title: What historical figure gets an undeserved bad reputation?

author.bio: You've come here to dig up dirt, probably because you lost an argument and are now resorting to petty tactics. My opinions may offend, in a free society that's acceptable. Much love and peace.

body:
**Public works and roads (See "Motorways in Italy and abroad" of the T.C.I.)**

* 1925 Inauguration of the Milan - Varese - Sesto Calende highway (the first highway in the world); 84.007km, built in 16 months.
* 1927 Inauguration of the Milano - Bergamo motorway
* 1928 The A.A.S.S. was created. (Autonomous State Roads Company)
* 1930 The mountain section (between Borghetto di Verona and the border) of the Brenner road is rebuilt, including the construction of twelve bridges, including those on the Isarco in Prato Isarco, in Fiè, in Cam-podazzo, in Chiusa, Cantina Fredda, in Fortezza. The bridge over the Molina stream in Calalzo, the Marlengo bridge over the Adige near Merano and the monumental Druso bridge, with three arcate, on the Talvera stream in Bolzano.
* 1929 Inauguration of the Naples - Pompeii motorway
* 1931 Bergamo - Brescia motorway, built in two years, of 47.647 km.
* 1932 Inauguration of the Turin - Milan motorway, 127.00 km, built in six years.
* 1932 Inauguration of the Firenze - Mare motorway of 81.333 km.
* 1933 Venice - Padua motorway, 24,600 km.
* 1935 Genoa - Serravalle Scrivia highway. At the tollbooth of Serravalle Scrivia there is a sculpture com-memorandum with the writing "Year of commencement of works 1930, work completed 1933". The first large service area was built at the Genoa toll booth, comprising a building with restaurant, daytime hotel, post office and telegraph, bar, managerial activities, station manager accommodation.
Dams: hydroelectric plant on the Tirso (beginning)
Santa Chiara dam (beginning)
Dam on the Sele (Puglia)
* 1935 Palazzo di Giustizia in Milan: truly imposing marble construction (7 floors), in bundle style- It is. Built between 1935 and 1940, it is the seat of the Court of Milan.
* 1937 Inauguration of the new headquarters of the Research Council


**Technical**

* 1926 Delivery of the Norge airship to Amundsen
* 1928 Record of length and duration in flight: 8,000 km in 58 hours and 37 '
* 1928 E.I.A.R., Today RAI.
Research Institute directed by G. Marconi
* 1930 First Atlantic Cruise arriving in Rio de Janeiro
* 1933 Atlantic Cruise (to New York and Chicago, where the keys to the city are handed over to Balbo)
* 1935 Foundation of the LUCE Institute
* 1937 Lt. Mario Pezzi conquers the world record of height reaching 15,655 meters; the following year, with a propeller plane, it reaches 17,083 meters, a record still undefeated.
* 1937 Experimental television broadcasts to EIAR (avant-garde)
* 1937 Experimentation with engines fueled with wood gas generator Guidonia experimental center, equipped with the most important wind tunnel laboratory at the time. (destroyed in 1944)
* 1938 The first experiments on television date back to 1929; in 1938 the EIAR press office communicated that television services would begin in 1939. On 04/06/1939 at the Leonardo Exhibition there were some experimental broadcasts (see Radiocorriere of the time). The project was abandoned with the war.
Littoriali of culture and art.
Observatories of Trieste, Genoa, Merate, Brera, Campo Imperatore.


**Social life**

* 1923 Construction of the Monza racetrack
* 1931 One of the proponents of the change in the habits of Italians at the table was the fascist regime, both for the promotion, which he made by inventing festivals and reviews of national products and national cuisine, both because it strengthened the tendency to eat out during meetings, celebrations and above all travels such as popular trains, after work, sports and student associations. A perfect example of this is the first edition in 1931 of the Italian Gastronomic Guide by the Italian Touring Club, where the traveler-tourist is led to discover the local regional products in what is the first socio-political consecration of Italian gastronomy.
* 1932 Establishment of the Venice Film Festival, the first event of its kind in the world.
* 1935 Menu in restaurants is mandatory.
* 1935 Establishment of the fascist Saturday holiday
* Befana Holiday

**Libya**

* 1926 The Romagna concession was inaugurated in Libya (10,000 ha)
* 1937 20,000 Italian colonists moved, assigning them: already furnished dwelling house, stables with beasts, agricultural equipment and machinery.
26 agricultural villages were ready: Olivetti, Bianchi, Giordani, Micca, Tazzoli, Breviglieri, Marconi, Garabulli, Crispi, Corradini, Garibaldi, Littoriano, Castel Benito, Filzi, Baracca, Maddalena, Aro, O-berdan, D'Annunzio, Razza , Mameli, Battisti, Berta, Luigi di Savoia, Gioda. Ten more Libyan villages in which Berbers and natives learned from our farmers how to make the land bear fruit: El Fager (Alba),
Nahima (Deliziosa), Azizia (Scented), Nahiba (Risorta), Mansura (Vittoriosa), Chadra (Verde), Zahara (Fiorita), Gedina (Nuova), Mamhura (Fiorente), El Beida (the White) formerly Beda Littoria.
* 1937 The Arab knights offer him the sword of Islam


**Ethiopia**

* Abolition of slavery
* Works performed in Ethiopia: 60,000 national workers and 160,000 indigenous people unrolled on the territory more than
5,000 km of paved roads and 1,400 km of lorry tracks. They had transformed not only Addis Ababa, but also dark villages into large inhabited centers (Dessiè, Harar, Gondar, Dire, Daua). Hotels, schools, sewers, electricity, restaurants, connections with other empire centers, telegraph, telephone, ports, radio stations, airports, cinemas and theaters. They created new markets, numerous schools for indigenous people, and for indigenous people created: tuberculars, hospices for old and disabled people, hospitals for maternity and children, leper colony. 
That of Selaclacà: over 700 beds and a great institute for studies and research against leprosy. They created colonization businesses in the form of state-funded cooperatives, mills, breweries, tobacco factories, cement factories, oil mills, cultivating more than 75,000 hectares of land.

guild.description:
Ask and answer questions.

Rules:

🤔 Posts must be questions. This is a community dedicated to Q&A discussion, so post titles must be in the form of a question.

⁉️ No loaded questions.

📬 No spamming. Spamming comments or posts is not allowed.

😀 Be civil. Be nice. Harassment, trolling, and disruptive behavior is not allowed. Basically, don’t be a jerk.

🥾 Breaking these rules will result in posts being kicked and possibly an exile.

📜 Follow Ruqqus ToS. This is a given.

* 1936 Cinecittà Foundation - In 1935, after the destruction due to a fire, the studies of the house of Cinema production, was identified along the via Tuscolana, in the middle of the Roman countryside, an area of ​​approximately 500,000 square meters for the construction of the new city of cinema. Work began on January 26, 1936 with the laying of the first stone and after only fifteen months, on April 28, 1937, the inauguration of the new Quadraro factories took place. The plans for the first twelve stage theaters were elaborated by the architect Gino Peressuti; in addition to these, the creation of an industrial center was envisaged integrated cinematographic strial which included development, printing and assembly plants, the new headquarters of the Istituto Luce and that of the Centro Sperimentale di Cinematografia.
* 1937 Rural and Artisan Boxes - R.D. 26/08/1937 n. 1706
* 1944 Corporate socialization - Law of the R.S.I.

**Railways**

* 1931 Inauguration of the new Milan central railway station. Construction had started in 1913 but then suspended for the war. With a new design and with 341 meter long steel arches (covering an area of ​​66,500 square meters), construction began at a steady pace in 1925. The facade is 200 meters wide and the vault 72 is high (a record by then) . It is still considered one of the most beautiful stations in the world. Inauguration of the Santa Maria Novella station in Florence
* 1932 Rome - Viterbo railway inaugurated
* 1934 The direct Bologna - Florence route was inaugurated
* 1934 The Littorina is born: one of these railcars makes the 12,000 km trip Turin, Moscow, Leningrad, Black Sea, Moscow, Turin. It makes the crossing Baltic Sea - Black Sea in 35 hours (25 hours less of the fastest local trains, setting a record of time still unbeaten). The entire network was enlarged and almost electrified; the replaced rolling stock. Italy had the most equipped and efficient railway network in Europe.
* 1938 Beginning of the Rome metropolitan construction (60% completed in 1940)
* 1923 Forestry Code (establishment of the Forestry Guard)
* 1923 Law on hydraulic reclamation and soil protection
* 1923 Law on agricultural transformations of public interest
* 1923 Establishment of the State Archive
* 1927 The Labor Charter was published
* 1928 Mussolini Law: Complete remediation with works entrusted to the ONC - R.D. 24/12/1928 n. 3134
* 1929 Signature of the Lateran Pacts
* 1930 Criminal Code
* 1933 Code of Criminal Procedure
* 1933 Bank and Circular Check Law
* 1936 Tourism legislation
* 1936 Banking law. It reorganizes the banking system and prohibits ordinary credit banks from making long-term loans.
* 1940 Code of Civil Procedure
* 1940 Navigation Code
* 1942 Civil Code
Consolidated Law on Public Safety Laws
Traffic laws

**Social laws**

* 1923 School Reform (Gentile Reform)
* 1923 The activity of the Mussolini government was a constant succession of decrees and laws with clear social aims at the forefront not only in Italy but even in the world. Those laws, of which the Italian workers still enjoy the privileges, are those desired by Mussolini in his twenty years of government. Any comparison with what has been done by the governments of this post-war period would be striking.
* 1923 Disability and old-age insurance - R.D. 30/12/1923 n. 3184
* 1923 Hospital assistance to the poor - R.D. 30/12/2003 n. 2841
* 1923 Protection of the work of women and children - R.D. 26/04/1923 n. 653
* 1923 Establishment of full trade unionism with the union of employers' trade union representatives (Confindustria and Confagricoltura)
* 1925 National Opera Maternity and Childhood (O.N.M.I.) - R.D. 10/12/1925 n. 2277. They came to visit works foreign speakers to study its organization (in 1934 the Chinese delegation)
* 1925 Illegitimate and abandoned or exposed assistance - R.D. 08/05/1925 n. 798
* 1926 Unemployment insurance - R.D. 12/30/1926 n. 3158
* 1927 Labor Charter (see Economy)
* 1927 Compulsory assistance against TB - Constitution of Provincial Consortia - R.D. 27/10/1927 n. 2055
* 1928 Tax exemption for large families - R.D. 05/14/1928 n. 1312
* 1928 Compulsory insurance against occupational diseases - R.D. 13/05/1928 n. 928
* 1929 National Opera Orphans of War - R.D. 26/07/1929 n. 1397
* 1935 I.N.P.S. - National Social Security Institute - R.D. 04/10/1935 n. 1827
* 1937 40-hour working week - R.D. 29/05/1937 n. 1768
* 1933 I.N.A.I.L .: National Institute for Insurance against Accidents at Work - R.D. 23/03/1933 n. 264
* 1937 E.C.A .: Municipal Assistance Body - R.D. 03/06/1937 n. 817
* 1937 Family allowances - R.D. 17/06/1937 n. 1048
* 1943 I.N.A.M .: Institute for Worker Illness Assistance - R.D. 11/01/1943 n. 138
Autonomous Institute of Popular Houses
National Institute for State Employee Homes
National Opera Dopolavoro (in 1935 it had 771 cinemas, 1227 theaters, 2066 theater, 2130 orchestras, 3787 bands, 1032 professional and cultural associations, 6427 libraries, 994 choral schools, 11159 sports sections, 4427 competitive sports.). The communists called it the people's house.
Fight against illiteracy: from 1923 to 1936 we went from 3,981,000 to 5,187,000 pupils; Student's medium teeth from 326,604 to 674,546, university from 43,235 to 71,512.
After-school for the completion of the pupils
Physical education compulsory in schools
Fight against malaria
Marine and mountain colonies
School meals
Scholastic obligation up to 14 years
Professional schools
Labor Judiciary
School card
FAO foundation

**Mafia**

Another "great success" of the regime was the fight against the mafia. The protagonist of this enterprise was
Cesare Mori, the so-called "Iron Prefect".

When Mussolini came to power, finding himself among other things facing the problem of banditry and the Sicilian mafia, he was made the name of Mori. Mussolini said: "I want it to be just as hard on the mobsters as it has been on my Bolognese squads." "State authority must be absolutely, I repeat absolutely, re-established in Sicily. If the laws currently in force obstruct it, it will not be a problem. We will make new laws. " Even if the mafia was not completely liquidated, it fell so to speak "to sleep". The American godparents who returned to the island in 1943 after the landing of the Allied troops will wake it up.

**Marina**

* 1925 Civil and military marine enhancement: in 1932 it is among the most important in the world
* 1931 Launch of the Amerigo Vespucci school ship
Genoa's new maritime station
Launch of the transatlantic Rex: the most sophisticated and fastest ship in the world: Gibraltar New York in 4 days, 13 hours and 58 minutes.
* 1937 The battleship Vittorio Veneto was launched
* 1940 Completion of the Porto Marghera basin to bring ships to the armament plants and repair
Port of Naples
Port of Messina

**Architectural works and infrastructures**

* 1927 Idroscalo of Milan. In 1927 Fascism passed a law for the construction of a "Idroscalo" for the city of Milan. Real sea, even salty, sandy shore, marine pines, bathers, lifeguards. The "Idroscalo" is a large gully 3 km long and 300 meters wide with 300 head for aircraft maneuvers. The basin occupies an area of ​​610,000 square meters. It is fed by spring waters. The Idroscalo has always been- to reported as quagmire. The Duce has transformed it into a basin, a lake, a "slice" of sea with all marine characteristics. This spectacular miracle was inaugurated in 1930. The beach has 100 cabins, has its "promenade", with trees around it, hotels, amusement parks, sports fields, meadows. At the center of the basin there is an island that can be easily reached by boat and find all the fun there.
Palazzo della Previdenza Sociale in each provincial capital
* 1930 Verona: General warehouses with cutting-edge refrigeration systems in Europe
Rome: Viale della Conciliazione
Rome: Metro
Rome: Stadio dei Marmi (in front of the huge obelisk with the inscription "Mussolini Dux")
Rome: University city inaugurated in 1935
Rome: Palazzo della Farnesina, seat of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs
Rome: foundation of Cinecittà (works started in 1936, finished in 1937)
* 1931/4 Venice. In 657 days the bridge of the Littorio (today of Liberty) was built, which connects Venice to the mainland. And since towards the end the engineer Eugenio Miozzi realized he had spent less than he spent they had given him, he decided to use the surplus to build, in front of the railway station, a new bridge that would cross the Grand Canal, the Scalzi bridge (built in Istrian stone, without any armor). The work began 9 days after the inauguration of the Ponte del Littorio by the Duce and was ready in 542 days. And since towards the end of this second work he realized that he had spent less than expected, he decided to demolish the old iron bridge of the Academy (in pitiful conditions) to replace it with a temporary wooden one. Felling, debris removal, construction of the new building and inauguration: one month. And the beautiful wooden bridge is still there. Creation of the car terminal in Piazzale Roma (1931-1933). Construction of the garage of Sant'Andrea, one of the major works of rationalist architecture in Venice (1931-1934). Construction of the Municipal Casino on the Lido (1937-1938).
* 1932 Rome: Inauguration of the new headquarters of the Ministry of Corporations
* 1937 Rome: EUR construction begins (was to be inaugurated in 1943)
* 1937 Rome: Construction of the National Light Institute begins
* 1938 Rome: Inauguration of the Ara Pacis
Rome: Via dell’Impero between the Colosseum and Piazza Venezia
Creation of the Empire architectural style
* 1928 The Venice Biennale is born
